race.name: Ride the Gravel Trails
race.tagline: Ride the Gravel Trails. 60 miles of gravel through Dakota County.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Minnesota countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Minnesota event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Ride the Gravel Trails is a local event in Minnesota—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Minnesota countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Minnesota gravel race. Worth it for Minnesota/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Minnesota—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Minnesota races: Gray Duck Grit, Almanzo 100.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Dakota County has good lodging options.
logistics.food: Dakota County has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Ride the Gravel Trails website

non_negotiables.why: Minnesota rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: No documented start locations, parking arrangements, or registration systems found across Minnesota gravel event calendars. Dakota County's proximity to Minneapolis provides decent airport access and lodging options, but race-specific logistics remain undocumented.

length.explanation: 60 miles hits the sweet spot for most gravel riders - long enough to matter, short enough to finish before dark. That distance works well in Dakota County's rolling terrain, though no mapped course has been verified.

technicality.explanation: Dakota County trails are generally smooth compared to northern Minnesota's rocky terrain. Mostly doubletrack and rail-trail surfaces that don't demand advanced handling skills or risk equipment damage.

elevation.explanation: 2600 feet over 60 miles averages about 43 feet per mile - rolling but not brutal. Dakota County offers enough ups and downs to keep things interesting without delivering mountain climbing suffering.

climate.explanation: Minnesota weather swings from frozen conditions to humid heat depending on timing. Spring races risk mud and cold, summer brings thunderstorms, but no race date information is available for planning.

altitude.explanation: Dakota County sits around 900 feet above sea level. Even riders from sea level won't notice any elevation effects - your biggest concern is remembering to pump your tires.

adventure.explanation: Riding Dakota County gravel offers mild adventure with decent scenery and trail variety. Suburban Minnesota delivers pleasant countryside riding rather than epic wilderness sufferfests.

prestige.explanation: This race doesn't exist in any meaningful cycling database or Minnesota gravel calendar. If you can't find a race on the internet in 2025, it's either fictional or so small it might as well be.

race_quality.explanation: No course marking details, aid station setup, or timing systems documented anywhere. The 60-mile distance and elevation profile suggest reasonable planning concepts, but operational details remain absent.

experience.explanation: Dakota County has solid trail systems, but without any rider testimonials or race reports, you're flying blind. Minnesota's gravel scene is strong enough that a 60-miler would generate some buzz. The silence is telling.

community.explanation: Dakota County sits in the Minneapolis metro where gravel riding is popular among local cyclists. The area has active recreational trail users, though no documented race community or organized event participation exists.

field_depth.explanation: Zero documented finishers means zero field depth. Real Minnesota gravel races like the Almanzo or Dirty Benjamin pull competitive fields. This phantom event doesn't appear on any serious rider's calendar.

value.explanation: Dakota County offers excellent gravel trail access without race fees since no registration system exists. The area provides quality riding terrain at standard Minnesota costs without event markup.

expenses.explanation: Minneapolis metro proximity keeps lodging and travel costs reasonable. No race-specific fees documented, so expenses would be limited to standard travel costs like gas and potentially a hotel.
